questions.question: Section 1031 allows for:

options.A: Tax-free exchange of any business property
options.B: Deferral of gain on exchange of like-kind real property
options.C: Exclusion of gain on any property exchange
options.D: Deferral of gain on exchange of personal property

questions.explanation: Section 1031 allows for DEFERRAL (not exclusion) of gain when like-kind real property held for business or investment is exchanged for other like-kind real property. The gain is deferred until the replacement property is sold.
questions.tip: Section 1031 = deferral, not exclusion. Only real property now (TCJA changed this).

questions.question: After the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act, Section 1031 applies only to:

options.B: Personal property only
options.C: Real property used in business or held for investment
options.D: Vehicles and equipment

questions.explanation: TCJA limited Section 1031 to real property only, effective for exchanges after December 31, 2017. Previously, personal property like vehicles and equipment could qualify. Now only real estate qualifies for like-kind exchange treatment.
questions.tip: Post-TCJA: Section 1031 = REAL PROPERTY ONLY. No more equipment, vehicles, etc.

questions.question: For real property, 'like-kind' means:

options.B: Any real property for any other real property regardless of type
options.C: Property of equal value
options.D: Property in the same state

questions.explanation: For real property, like-kind is broadly interpreted. Any real property held for business or investment can be exchanged for any other real property. An office building can be exchanged for farmland, raw land for apartments, etc.
questions.tip: Real estate like-kind = very broad. Any real property for any real property.

questions.question: In a like-kind exchange, 'boot' refers to:

options.B: Non-like-kind property received, such as cash or debt relief
options.C: Transaction costs
options.D: The property given up

questions.explanation: Boot is non-like-kind property received in the exchange, including cash, debt relief, and other property. Receipt of boot triggers gain recognition to the extent of the boot received (limited to realized gain).
questions.tip: Boot = the extra stuff (cash, debt relief). Receiving boot triggers taxable gain.

questions.question: Property held primarily for sale (dealer property) in a like-kind exchange:

options.B: Does not qualify for Section 1031 treatment
options.C: Qualifies only if held for more than one year
options.D: Qualifies if exchanged for investment property

questions.explanation: Property held primarily for sale to customers (inventory or dealer property) does not qualify for Section 1031 treatment. Both the property given up and the property received must be held for productive use in trade/business or for investment.
questions.tip: Dealer property = no 1031. Must be held for business use or investment, not sale.

questions.question: A personal residence exchanged for another personal residence:

options.B: Does not qualify because personal-use property is excluded
options.C: Qualifies if held for more than 2 years
options.D: Qualifies under Section 121 rules

questions.explanation: Personal-use property, including a personal residence, does not qualify for Section 1031 treatment. The property must be held for productive use in trade or business or for investment. Personal residences may qualify for Section 121 exclusion instead.
questions.tip: Personal use property = no 1031. Principal residence = use Section 121 instead.

questions.question: In a like-kind exchange, gain is recognized to the extent of:

options.B: The lesser of boot received or gain realized
options.C: The boot received regardless of gain
options.D: The fair market value of property received

questions.explanation: Gain is recognized to the extent of the lesser of: (1) boot received, or (2) gain realized. You cannot be taxed on more boot than you receive, and you cannot recognize more gain than you actually have.
questions.tip: Recognized gain = lesser of boot or realized gain. Can't recognize more than either.

questions.question: In a like-kind exchange where a loss is realized:

options.B: The loss is recognized to the extent of boot received
options.C: No loss is recognized
options.D: The loss is carried forward

questions.explanation: Losses in like-kind exchanges are never recognized, even if boot is received. The loss is deferred by carrying over the loss into a higher basis in the replacement property. This differs from gain treatment.
questions.tip: 1031 losses = NEVER recognized (deferred). Unlike gains which are recognized with boot.

questions.question: When the other party assumes a mortgage on property given up in a 1031 exchange, the taxpayer:

options.B: Is treated as receiving boot equal to the debt relief
options.C: Must recognize a loss
options.D: Increases basis in new property

questions.explanation: Mortgage relief (having debt assumed by the other party) is treated as boot received. The taxpayer is relieved of a liability, which is economically equivalent to receiving cash. This triggers gain recognition to the extent of the relief.
questions.tip: Debt relief = boot received. Getting out of a mortgage = taxable boot.

questions.question: When both properties in a 1031 exchange have mortgages, the boot is calculated by:

options.B: Netting the mortgages to determine net relief or assumption
options.C: Ignoring the mortgages entirely
options.D: Using only the larger mortgage amount

questions.explanation: When both parties exchange mortgaged properties, the mortgages are netted. Boot is determined by net debt relief (debt relieved minus debt assumed). Only net relief creates boot; assuming more debt than relieved creates no boot but requires cash or other boot to balance.
questions.tip: Net the mortgages: (debt relieved - debt assumed). Net relief = boot received.

questions.question: The basis of property received in a like-kind exchange equals:

options.A: Fair market value of property received
options.B: Basis of property given up - boot received + boot given + gain recognized
options.C: The cost of the replacement property
options.D: Zero

questions.explanation: The substituted basis formula: Basis of new property = Basis of old property - Boot received + Boot given + Gain recognized - Loss recognized. This formula ensures deferred gain is preserved in the new property's basis.
questions.tip: New basis = old basis - boot received + boot given + gain recognized.

questions.question: In a deferred like-kind exchange, replacement property must be identified within:

options.A: 30 days of relinquishing the old property
options.B: 45 days of relinquishing the old property
options.C: 90 days of relinquishing the old property
options.D: 180 days of relinquishing the old property

questions.explanation: The taxpayer must identify potential replacement property within 45 days of transferring the relinquished property. The identification must be in writing and signed, and generally up to three properties can be identified (or more under certain rules).
questions.tip: 45-day identification deadline. 180-day acquisition deadline. Both are hard deadlines.

questions.question: In a deferred exchange, replacement property must be received within:

options.B: 90 days
options.C: 180 days or the due date of the tax return, whichever is earlier
options.D: One year

questions.explanation: The replacement property must be received by the earlier of: (1) 180 days after the transfer of the relinquished property, or (2) the due date (including extensions) of the tax return for the year of the transfer.
questions.tip: 180 days OR tax return due date, whichever is earlier. Get an extension if needed!

questions.question: A qualified intermediary in a 1031 exchange:

options.A: Must be a bank or financial institution
options.B: Holds proceeds from the sale and acquires replacement property on the taxpayer's behalf
options.C: Is optional in all exchanges
options.D: Can be the taxpayer's attorney or CPA

questions.explanation: A qualified intermediary facilitates deferred exchanges by holding sale proceeds (avoiding constructive receipt by the taxpayer) and acquiring replacement property. The QI cannot be the taxpayer, their agent, or certain related parties.
questions.tip: QI holds the money so you don't touch it. Touching proceeds = taxable sale.

questions.question: Under the three-property rule, a taxpayer in a deferred exchange may identify:

options.B: Up to three replacement properties regardless of their value
options.C: Unlimited properties if their total value doesn't exceed 200% of relinquished property
options.D: Properties only in the same state

questions.explanation: The three-property rule allows identification of up to three properties without regard to their fair market value. Alternative rules include the 200% rule (unlimited properties if total FMV ≤ 200% of relinquished) or 95% rule (must acquire 95% of identified value).
questions.tip: 3-property rule: up to 3 properties, any value. Alternative: 200% rule or 95% rule.

questions.question: In a like-kind exchange between related parties, Section 1031 treatment is lost if:

options.B: Either party disposes of the property within 2 years
options.C: The parties are family members
options.D: The exchange is simultaneous

questions.explanation: When a like-kind exchange occurs between related parties, both parties must hold their property for at least 2 years or the exchange is disqualified. Exceptions exist for death, involuntary conversion, or exchanges where tax avoidance was not a principal purpose.
questions.tip: Related party 1031: 2-year holding period for BOTH parties or it's disqualified.

questions.question: The holding period of replacement property in a like-kind exchange:

options.A: Starts fresh on the date of the exchange
options.B: Includes the holding period of the relinquished property (tacking)
options.C: Is always considered long-term
options.D: Is determined by the 45-day rule

questions.explanation: The holding period of the relinquished property 'tacks' onto the replacement property. This means if the taxpayer held the old property for 5 years, the new property immediately has a 5-year holding period for capital gain purposes.
questions.tip: Holding period tacks in 1031. New property inherits old property's holding period.

questions.question: Cash boot given in an exchange can offset:

options.B: Boot received from mortgage relief only
options.C: Both cash boot received and mortgage relief
options.D: Nothing - boot given has no effect

questions.explanation: Cash (or FMV of other property) given can offset mortgage boot received but NOT cash boot received. If you give cash and receive cash, they don't net. But cash given can offset debt relief to reduce recognized gain.
questions.tip: Cash given offsets debt relief, NOT cash received. Important distinction!

questions.question: When depreciable property is received in a 1031 exchange, depreciation is calculated on:

options.A: The fair market value of the replacement property
options.B: The carryover basis plus any additional investment
options.C: Only the additional cash invested
options.D: The original cost of the relinquished property

questions.explanation: The exchanged basis (carryover portion) continues the depreciation method and life of the relinquished property. Any additional basis from boot given or recognized gain is depreciated as if newly purchased property.
questions.tip: Split the basis: carryover portion = continue old depreciation; new basis = fresh start.

questions.question: U.S. real property exchanged for foreign real property:

options.B: Does not qualify - U.S. and foreign property are not like-kind
options.C: Qualifies if the properties have similar use
options.D: Qualifies only if no boot is involved

questions.explanation: U.S. real property and foreign real property are NOT considered like-kind. An exchange must be U.S. property for U.S. property OR foreign property for foreign property. This is one of the few restrictions on real property like-kind treatment.
questions.tip: U.S. real property ≠ foreign real property for 1031. Different categories.

questions.question: Exchange expenses (commissions, title fees) in a 1031 exchange are treated as:

options.B: Reducing the amount of boot received or increasing basis
options.C: Ignored for tax purposes
options.D: Capital losses

questions.explanation: Exchange expenses reduce the amount realized (like reducing boot received) or are added to basis. They can effectively reduce recognized gain by offsetting boot. They are not separately deductible as expenses.
questions.tip: Exchange costs reduce boot (or increase basis). Help minimize taxable gain.

questions.question: In a reverse like-kind exchange:

options.A: The replacement property is acquired before the relinquished property is sold
options.B: Cash is received before property
options.C: The exchange is between related parties
options.D: Multiple properties are exchanged

questions.explanation: A reverse exchange occurs when the taxpayer acquires replacement property before disposing of the relinquished property. An exchange accommodation titleholder (EAT) holds title to one property. Safe harbor requires parking the property for no more than 180 days.
questions.tip: Reverse exchange = buy new before selling old. Use EAT to hold property temporarily.

questions.question: In an improvement (build-to-suit) exchange, the taxpayer can:

options.A: Immediately take possession of replacement property being improved
options.B: Have improvements made to replacement property held by an EAT within the exchange period
options.C: Improve their own property with exchange proceeds
options.D: Defer gain only on the land portion

questions.explanation: An improvement exchange allows the taxpayer to acquire property and have improvements made using exchange proceeds before taking title. An EAT holds the property while improvements are made, which must be completed within the 180-day period.
questions.tip: Build-to-suit: EAT holds property while improvements made. Must finish in 180 days.

questions.question: When a taxpayer in a 1031 exchange receives both like-kind property and boot:

options.B: Gain is recognized only to the extent of boot received, limited to realized gain
options.C: The transaction is treated as two separate sales
options.D: Loss is recognized to the extent of boot

questions.explanation: Receiving boot doesn't disqualify the exchange—it just triggers recognition of gain to the extent of the lesser of boot received or gain realized. The exchange still defers gain on the like-kind property received.
questions.tip: Boot triggers partial recognition, not disqualification. Still a valid 1031.

questions.question: When exchanging property that includes both land (qualifying) and personal property (non-qualifying):

options.B: Each asset is treated separately with only the real property qualifying
options.C: All property is treated as like-kind
options.D: The exchange must be restructured

questions.explanation: When an exchange involves both qualifying real property and non-qualifying personal property, the exchange is bifurcated. The real property exchange qualifies for 1031; the personal property is a separate taxable transaction.
questions.tip: Mixed exchanges: split qualifying real property from non-qualifying personal property.

questions.question: When boot in a 1031 exchange includes an installment note:

options.A: The installment method cannot be used
options.B: Gain from the boot can be reported using the installment method
options.C: All gain must be recognized immediately
options.D: The entire exchange is taxable

questions.explanation: If boot includes an installment note, the taxpayer can use the installment method to report gain from the boot as payments are received. This provides additional deferral beyond the 1031 deferral on the like-kind property.
questions.tip: Boot note = can use installment method. Double deferral potential.

questions.question: Interests in partnerships that own real property:

options.B: Do not qualify for 1031 treatment (specifically excluded)
options.C: Qualify if the partnership is domestic
options.D: Qualify if the partnership holds only real property

questions.explanation: Partnership interests are specifically excluded from Section 1031 treatment, regardless of what the partnership owns. However, tenant-in-common interests and Delaware statutory trust interests in real property may qualify.
questions.tip: Partnership interests = no 1031. But TIC interests and DST interests OK.

questions.question: The 'drop and swap' planning technique involves:

options.A: Exchanging property and then dropping out of the deal
options.B: Distributing property from a partnership to partners who then do individual 1031 exchanges
options.C: Swapping properties between related entities
options.D: Dropping the price to facilitate an exchange

questions.explanation: In a drop and swap, a partnership distributes property to partners (as TIC interests), and each partner then does their own 1031 exchange. This allows partners with different investment goals to each pursue separate exchanges.
questions.tip: Drop and swap: partnership distributes TIC interests, then partners do separate 1031s.

questions.question: A taxpayer can combine Section 1031 and Section 121 when:

options.B: Converting a rental property to a principal residence before sale
options.C: Exchanging a personal residence
options.D: The properties are in different states

questions.explanation: A taxpayer can convert rental property to a principal residence, live in it for 2+ years, then sell and use both Section 121 (exclude gain up to limits) and Section 1031 (for any investment portion). Complex rules apply to these hybrid situations.
questions.tip: Can combine 121 and 1031 with careful planning. Rental → residence → sale.

questions.question: Depreciation recapture in a 1031 exchange is:

options.B: Deferred along with other gain if no boot is received
options.C: Never applicable to real property
options.D: Only applicable to personal property exchanges

questions.explanation: Depreciation recapture (unrecaptured Section 1250 gain for real property) is deferred in a 1031 exchange if no boot is received. If boot is received, recapture is recognized first, then remaining gain. The recapture potential carries over to the new property.
questions.tip: Recapture is deferred in 1031 (no boot). Boot triggers recapture recognition first.

questions.question: The risk of qualified intermediary bankruptcy can be mitigated by:

options.B: Using qualified escrow accounts and requiring QI bonding/insurance
options.C: Only using bank QIs
options.D: Completing exchanges within 45 days

questions.explanation: QI bankruptcy risk (taxpayer loses funds if QI fails) can be mitigated by requiring qualified escrow or trust accounts (funds held by third party), QI bonding or fidelity insurance, and choosing financially stable QIs.
questions.tip: Protect exchange funds: qualified escrow, bonding, insurance. QI bankruptcy = you lose.

questions.question: A Delaware Statutory Trust (DST) interest is treated for 1031 purposes as:

options.B: An undivided interest in real property (qualifying)
options.C: A security (disqualifying)
options.D: Personal property (disqualifying post-TCJA)

questions.explanation: Per IRS Revenue Ruling 2004-86, properly structured DST interests are treated as direct interests in real property for 1031 purposes. This allows 1031 exchange into passive real estate investments without partnership interest disqualification.
questions.tip: DST = treated as real property interest for 1031. Popular for passive investors.

questions.question: In an exchange where the taxpayer gives property with basis of $100,000 and FMV of $250,000, and receives property worth $220,000 plus $30,000 cash, the recognized gain is:
questions.explanation: Realized gain = $250,000 (FMV given) - $100,000 (basis) = $150,000. Boot received = $30,000 cash. Recognized gain = lesser of boot ($30,000) or realized gain ($150,000) = $30,000. The remaining $120,000 is deferred.
questions.tip: Calculate: (1) Realized gain, (2) Boot received, (3) Recognized = lesser of the two.

questions.question: Using the same facts (basis $100K, FMV given $250K, received property $220K + $30K cash), the basis of the replacement property is:
questions.explanation: Basis formula: Old basis ($100,000) - Boot received ($30,000) + Boot given ($0) + Gain recognized ($30,000) = $100,000. Alternatively: FMV received ($220,000) - Deferred gain ($120,000) = $100,000.
questions.tip: New basis = old basis - boot received + boot given + gain recognized. Or: FMV - deferred gain.

questions.question: When gain is recognized in a 1031 exchange due to boot, the character of the gain is:

options.B: Always long-term capital gain
options.C: The same character as if the property had been sold (Section 1231, recapture, etc.)
options.D: Determined by the type of boot received

questions.explanation: Recognized gain in a 1031 exchange retains the character it would have had if the property were sold. This means Section 1231 property produces 1231 gain, and depreciation recapture (Section 1245/1250) is recognized first if applicable.
questions.tip: Gain character = same as if sold. Recapture recognized before other gain.
